text: <@U3E2EEX38|name_gone> has joined the channel
are you using nay styles?
any*
The style might be overriding the text color
also the tabLayout has an unselected and selected state
you probably need to set the color in both states
i'm not using any styles
what do you mean  states??
<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/drawable/StateListDrawable.html>
You should set a listener via setOnTabSelectedListener(OnTabSelectedListener) to be notified when any tab's selection state has been changed.
<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/design/widget/TabLayout.html>
when the state of the TabLayout changes from selected to unselected the text color can change

ColorStateList	getTabTextColors()
Gets the text colors for the different states (normal, selected) used for the tabs.
<https://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/design/widget/TabLayout.html#getTabTextColors()>
Does that help?
android.support.design:tabSelectedTextColor
set that aswell
in XML
if you only want one color
for every tab
then you dont need the listener
<@U37BP6E73> Leak Canary is great, it saves you time from manually going through your memory dump to find the zero ref, or GC root

<@U3697FDAN> How do you handle device rotations with that architecture? I have a similar architecture, I use MVP, with dagger and RxJava. I have a single Activity, and each feature/page of my app, extends from a ViewGroup. I had to write a custom back stack manager with saving states across rotations and app closures. I just insert a view into the activity and remove the old one as and when I need to, it makes it super fast, it even works with transitions. My actual custom back stack, doesn't require any design pattern, it can be used with MVP or not, but you must use viewGroups and a single activity. Its one line of code to setup the back stack and one line of code each time you want to insert or remove a view. I'm thinking of putting the back stack library on github, but i'm not sure anyone would be interested, since there are other similar ones available.
Depends on how you are managing state bro
Hi guys question
<@U08GFT5V5> what do you mean?

so I am taking picture, I launch the camera app, took a shot and when I load the image as "thumbnail" if I shot the pic vertically, it shows up as a rectanglar image (vertical). Is there a way to tell the camera to save the pic at a certain dip? Say I want to save it as 64dp with width and height being equal?
Architecture is just abstraction and organization
Depending on what kind of state management you have in mind
How you deal with orientation can simply be a matter of serializing and deserializing your state objects
Simplicity is generally your friend here.

<@U08GFT5V5>:  Architecture is just abstraction I agree. In my case I am not using any fragments as I find them bloated and having to much lifecycle dependencies. I extend from view group, saving and restoring the state while managing a back stack of views within a single activity isn't that easy, well at least it wasn't for me. What would you do to solve that problem?
<@U379MC1E0>:  Sorry I haven't worked with the camera yet
<@U08GFT5V5>:  There is a reason I used this architecture, it's easy to manage, easy to insert new views any time, and the app feels fast and responsive
